comments.body:
The filter text controls how the editor filters out completion items client-side as the user types more characters. 

![2019-04-06 11 37 00](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1408093/55667710-56549800-5860-11e9-8294-d01b11fac713.gif)

- on `override` completion, filter text should be `"override def $name"`
- on `def` completion, filter text should be `"def name"`
- on `val` completion, filter text should be `"val name"`

comments.body:
```suggestion
        val isExplicitlyCalled = suffix.startsWith(prefix)
```

```suggestion
        if ((shouldShow || isExpilicitelyCalled) && allParams.count(!_.hasDefault) > 1) {
```
For example, `pprint.log` has only one non-default parameter
When is filter not `"autofill"`?

It's always `autofill`, at least part of it. This is because I wanted it to be the last option and not show up before any legit completions. The suffix in that case is not that important, it just needs to be something so that it goes later in the list.

The sort text determines the order while the filter text determines what completion match what the user types. I'm struggling to understand the logic behind `if (isExpilicitelyCalled) suffix else prefix + suffix`, what is the difference between that and `"autofill"`?

Ach right,  I was wrong, this was done to show autofill when parameters are completed.
Nothing actually to do with sorting, sorry!
I would personally be in favor of not presenting autofill completions unless the user has typed a prefix of `"autofill"` or the empty string.
Will leave it also when writing parameter names for now. I think it can be much more useful this way, otherwise nobody will find it. If that proves to be problematic, I will remove it myself.
nit: we can extract this list and reuse between "override member" and "implement all" completions

So i'm not 100% sure what's happening here. I originally tried to reuse this iterator, but couldn't get it to work. For example, when I change this block to the below

```scala
          val members = typed.tpe.members.iterator

          val overrideMembers: List[OverrideDefMember] =
            members
              .filter(isOverridableMethod)
              .map(OverrideCandidate.apply)
              .filter { candidate =>
                CompletionFuzzy.matchesSubCharacters(
                  prefix,
                  candidate.filterText
                )
              }
              .map(_.toMember)
              .toList

          val allAbstractMembers = members
            .filter(isOverridableMethod)
            .map(OverrideCandidate.apply)
            .map(_.toMember)
            .filter(_.sym.isAbstract)
            .toList
            .map(_.edit.getNewText)
```
the individual overrides still appear in the completions, but the `allAbstractMembers` won't appear at all in the completion list. I'm not fully sure I understand why. Any insight on the best way to reuse this?

Iterators can only be consumed once. You can work around it with

```diff
-          val members = typed.tpe.members.iterator
+          val members = typed.tpe.members.iterator.toList
```
Ahh cool. I didn't know that. Thanks!

comments.body: this disables the `Autofill with default values` completion when the client does not support snippets, as per @tgodzik. Please review that it makes sense and that we can't find a good completion that works without snippets
Let's disable it for now, I will think it over to see if it makes sense without the snippets.
avoid the braces if we have no snippets. Inserting braces will result in a cursor out of place (`{}<CURSOR>`), which seems bad.

From my point of view, it is bad to end up with `foo{}<CURSOR>` after completion. I ran into a similar case with Apple's swift server and it forced me to do [this](https://github.com/bstaletic/ycmd/blob/swift/ycmd/completers/swift/swift_completer.py#L106-L110) - overriding completion algorithm for swift to strip `()` from `foo()`, even if there's something in between `(` and `)`.
thanks for the feedback! I'm actively avoiding that pattern, except in some cases where the completion is still very useful and/or it's opt-in (e.g. it's not the default case)

comments.body:
To insure ourselves against bad performance in pathological cases, we can cache the result of `indexOf` like this
```scala
@ List("z", "a", "b").iterator.zipWithIndex.toMap
res1: Map[String, Int] = Map("z" -> 0, "a" -> 1, "b" -> 2)
@ List("b", "z").sortBy(res1.get)
res3: List[String] = List("z", "b")
```

`indexOf` is linear and the callback to `sortBy` gets repeatedly called for each element.
Thanks! ðŸ‘  https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1174/commits/707a24f40d27f1bb528fa719742b417e89a06b06

comments.body:
What we construct scaladoc for is just `ClassDef` and `DefDef`, but collecting all the `MemberDef`  to avoid the following pattern.

```scala
/**@@
type Foo = Int // If we don't collect TypeDef

def foo(x: Int): Int = ???
```

to

```scala
/**
  *
  * @param x
  * @return
  */
type Foo = Int // If we don't collect TypeDef

def foo(x: Int): Int = ???
```

instead of 

```scala
/**
  *
  */
```

comments.body:
a multiline string is probably easier to read, for example:

```scala
s"""|
    |*
    |$lines
    |$returnLine
    |*/""".stripMargin
```
It's best IMO to use `StringBuilder` in cases like this, it more readable, easier to extend and it has the best performance.
:+1: to `StringBuilder` and done in https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1250/commits/e051eb5f80ea69b6b377c448705491de5a2ac836

comments.body: I don't understand the `lines.isEmpty` check. Also you can probably move `returnLine` inside the `if` branch in `newText` below

I meant to move the cursor to `@return | <- here` only if there are no parameters like

```scala
/**
   *
   * @return | <- here
   */
```

But now I'm going to move the cursor to the following position, we don't need this logic anymore.

```scala
/**
   * | <- here instead of after the @param
   *
   * @param
   * @return
   */
```

comments.body: It's expensive to split the entire file into lines for every single completion just to check if it's possibly a scaladoc completion. Is it possible to walk instead over the characters backwards and check one-by-one that the position is over `/**`?
Done:+1:  https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1250/commits/82618d1e3529cee4adc76c461ee79a45ad13583f

What happens for methods with context bounds?

```scala
/**@@
def foo[T: Ordering] = ...
```

Ah, I got something like 

```
/**
  *
  * @param evidence$1
  * @return
  */
def foo[T: Ordering] = ...
 ```

which is added around [here](https://github.com/scala/scala/blob/ba9701059216c629410f4f23a2175d20ad62484b/src/compiler/scala/tools/nsc/ast/parser/TreeBuilder.scala#L135).

Filtered out those synthetic params here https://github.com/scala/scala/blob/ba9701059216c629410f4f23a2175d20ad62484b/src/compiler/scala/tools/nsc/ast/parser/TreeBuilder.scala#L135 ðŸ‘

comments.body: Can we move all the scaladoc-related logic into a separate file? For example `ScaladocCompletions.scala`. The `Completions.scala` file is already too large.

Done in https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1250/commits/b6de5d98ad7ea7973b9363b3f72a4dc8c0b705ee ðŸ‘ 
Is it ok to split those files in this way?

If it's ok, I'd like to split other modules into another file in another PR (like MatchKeyword Completion related logics into `MatchKeywordCompletion.scala`)(in this case, maybe we should dig a directory like `completions` and put those files in `pc/completions/ScaladocCompletion.scala`)

as mentioned in https://github.com/scalameta/metals/issues/672

comments.body: Did you try `clazz.symbol.primaryConstructor`? In general, when using compiler APIs you want to operate on types and symbols instead of trees (unlike scalameta where we have mostly just trees)
Oh, I haven't tried it yet, I'm gonna give it a try!
Thanks! I could simplify the logic with `clazz.symbol.primaryConstructor` :) in https://github.com/scalameta/metals/pull/1250/commits/4f936d3f99045a68e038ebcab5774bf599a24f4e

comments.body:
Removed a `sealed` modifier to split `Scaladoc` related logic into another file.
I think we cannot avoid removing this for splitting each CompletionPosition logics into other files, and IMO it's ok with removing this modifier because we don't use exhaustive match for CompletionPosition ðŸ¤”
Just moved to `OverrideCompletions.scala`

Leaving `Type`, `New`, and `None` in `object CompletionPosition` because those CompletionPositions are small enough, and I couldn't see the benefit of splitting them into smaller files.
However, it might be better to split them into smaller files for consistency. ðŸ¤”
I think it would be better to be consistent here, but that's just my opinion. I am fine either way :)
